frame.name: Non-gradable_proximity
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Figure</fen> is characterized as near the <fen>Ground</fen>, according to some contextually given scale. Many lexical units of this frame additionally specify in which direction relative to the <fen>Ground</fen> one can find the <fen>Figure</fen> (under.prep, north.adv), or directions from the <fen>Ground</fen> from which the <fen>Figure</fen> is excluded (e.g. beside.prep excludes the vertical and front/back axes); for specifications of direction, see the semantic types attached to the lexcial units. Members of this frame that make reference to an absolute, earth-based grid (e.g. <ment>north</ment>, <ment>south</ment>, etc.) imply a geographic scale of proximity, and so are frequently not paraphrasable as "near".
<ex>She <ment>put</ment> <fex name="Figure">her shoes</fex> <t>under</t> <fex name="Ground">the table</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">Michael Jackson</fex> <m>was</m> <fex name="Distance">right</fex> <t>next to</t> <fex name="Ground">me</fex> !</ex> <ex><fex name="Direction">Down</fex> <t>by</t> <fex name="Ground">his left foot</fex> <m>was</m> <fex name="Figure">a little grenade</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex> The subset of LUs that inherently pick out a particular direction (e.g. <ment>north</ment>, <ment>behind</ment>) may occur with a specification of a <fen>Distance</fen> in that direction from a <fen>Ground</fen> at which the <fen>Figure</fen> may be found, while LUs that pick out two or more directions of relevance from a <fen>Ground</fen> (e.g. <ment>beside</ment>) can only characterize the general accessibility of the <fen>Figure</fen> relative to the <fen>Ground</fen>. <ex><fex name="Distance">30 miles</fex> <t>north</t></ex> <ex><fex name="Accessibility">right</fex> <t>beside</t> my leg</ex>
This frame is intended to cover a limited set of productive metaphor cases in which allegiance is expressed as a Devotee standing to one side or behind an Allegiance_holder:
<ex><fex name="Figure">I</fex> <m>stand</m> <t>beside</t> <fex name="Ground">what I said to him</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">They</fex> will <m>stand</m> <fex name="Accessibility">right</fex> <t>next to</t> <fex name="Ground">me</fex> in the fight against homophobia .</ex>
This frame is not intended for metaphorical cases of quantity specification:
<ex>There was <t>above</t> 500 kg of cocaine in the shipment .</ex>
This frame does not cover the multitude of other metaphorical cases like "next to impossible", "under consideration", "under his rule", "beside himself", "beside the point". </def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
<ex>The cat is <t>next to</t> <fex name="Grnd">the mat</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
<ex><fex name="Fig">The cat</fex> is <t>next to</t> the mat.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Accessibility
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how accessible the <fen>Figure</fen> is to some participant in the speech context (either the speaker or the addressee, or some other highly salient viewpoint in a narrative). This FE normally describes availability for manipulation and use, but may simply describe how easily seen or difficult to see the <fen>Figure</fen> is. There is a closed class of items that can fill this slot, including only 'just' and 'right' indicating ease of access, and 'way' and 'all the way' indicating distance and difficulty of access.
<ex>Oh yeah , the flashlight 's <fex name="Accessibility">right</fex> <t>by</t> my handbag .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Direction</fen> from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the <fen>Figure</fen>. This FE is filled by one of a closed class of adverbs: up, down, out (meaning 'beyond the boundary around the viewpoint'), off (meaning 'disconnect between landmark and figure'), back (meaning 'along a line from front to back of landmark, and relatively inaccessible'), and, more rarely, away, along, and dialectally, back down (meaning 'down and behind').
<ex>The cat is hiding <fex name="Dir">down</fex> <t>under</t> the porch.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
<ex>He was <t>by</t> the park <fex name="tim">on Friday</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Distance
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Distance</fen> between the <fen>Figure</fen> and the <fen>Ground</fen>. This FE requires an image schema with a vector that extends from the <fen>Ground</fen>, or a subpart of the <fen>Ground</fen>, in some direction, and the <fen>Distance</fen> is measured along this vector from the <fen>Ground</fen> to the profiled region. <ex>Go <fex name="Distance">30 feet</fex> to the <t>left</t> of the pool.</ex> Note that a number of frequent adverbial targets identify the <fen>Ground</fen>, with the location of an implicit viewer, so <fen>Distance</fen> is effectively measured from the viewpoint location in these cases. <ex>We were already <fex name="Distance">nearly 1000 meters</fex> <t>ahead</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Deixis
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how the locative phrase relates to the grounding of the speech situation, either locating it near (here) or far (there, yonder), or specifically separated from the speech context by distance or a barrier (over). Fillers of this FE are restricted to this closed class of items.
<ex>It is lying <fex name="Deixis">here</fex> <t>beside</t> the chair.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Directness
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how closely the position of <fen>Figure</fen> matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target. This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, directly, and due (and some combinations of these), but also occurs with rarer items like 'smack dab'.
<ex>I ran <fex name="Directness">right</fex> <t>along</t> the edge .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Temporal_profile
FE.definition:
<def-root>A description of how the access path to the <fen>Ground</fen> interacts with time. This FE is filled only by the closed class of adverbials back.adv (which indicates that the position was occupied by the <fen>Figure</fen> before) and on.adv (which indicates a continued path). While this FE in its most basic use refers to cases of actual motion, it can be used with descriptions of static position, in which case it either refers to fictive, imagined motion, or it backgrounds motion entirely (as in the example below).
<ex>They finally moved <fex name="Temporal_profile">back</fex> <t>east</t>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: by.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: located not far from.

lexUnit.name: beside.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: near and to the side of.

lexUnit.name: under.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: saliently impinging on and located in the direction of gravity (or the direction relative to the landmark that is conventionally associated with gravity) from.

lexUnit.name: underneath.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in a place below or beneath (in the direction conventionally associated with gravity) of.

lexUnit.name: behind.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: on the opposite side of

lexUnit.name: in front (of).prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in a position before or ahead of

lexUnit.name: in back (of).prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in a position behind or toward the rear of

lexUnit.name: ahead.adv
lexUnit.definition: FN: in a position before or to the front of

lexUnit.name: along.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: on, over, or parallel to the length of (typically for a rather horizontal axis)

lexUnit.name: neighboring.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: situated or living (being) near; adjacent

lexUnit.name: over.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in a place above (along the axis conventionally associated with gravity) of

lexUnit.name: opposite.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: located face-to-face with, across from, or at the other end of something

lexUnit.name: left [landmark-based].n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that is on or at the left side of the landmark in question

lexUnit.name: right [landmark-based].n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that is on or at the right side of the landmark in question

lexUnit.name: left [viewpoint-based].n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that is on or at the left side of the trajector/figure

lexUnit.name: right [viewpoint-based].n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that is on or at the right side of the trajector/figure

lexUnit.name: beneath.prep
lexUnit.definition: COD: extending or directly underneath.

lexUnit.name: opposite.prep
lexUnit.definition: COD: in a position opposite to.

lexUnit.name: starboard.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the right-hand side; usage is strictly nautical

lexUnit.name: port.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: to the left-hand side; usage is strictly nautical

lexUnit.name: on.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in immediate proximity to a side or surface of.
